bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 11, 1928

div1.p: Carter updates Russell on progress she and Brown have made on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and sends regards to Russell from Thayer.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, June 11, 1928
div1.opener:
Book
Russell (Dr. F.F.)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
June 11, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Thank you for your very interesting letter of June 5th.
I am so glad to hear that the yellow fever work is going forward rapidly and
much interested in the ten papers which you tell me are now in
press, which I hope I shall have the privelege of seeing.

Miss Brown and I have just put in an unusually success-
ful week, including yesterday, Sunday, when we worked together
from the time the Library of Congress opened until late in the
evening. Miss Brown is giving me every night now, as well as
part of every day, Sundays included. We both also take books
home and hunt up references before breakfast and late at night
so our combined efforts are beginning to show very satisfactory
results.

I am expecting Dr. Frost over here this week to go over
what I have done and to talk over what remains to be done. He
had intended coming sooner, but has had to be away from Baltimore
a good deal lately: giving addresses etc. I've offered to again take my
material to Baltimore, but he thinks he should also make a trip here

With very best wishes, and I know that I need not assure
you that I'm doing everything that I possibly can to hasten the
completion of the book.
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
P. S. I was in Baltimore for a few hours last week, in
connection with some maps. Had luncheon with Dr. Thayer, his
nephew and niece. Dr. Thayer asked after you most particularly.
